atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachyca: an unusually fast heart rate caused by an extra electrical connection that forms through the AV node (= area of the heart that transmits electrical impulses)
房室結折返性心動過速

attach to: To attach a particular quality to something is to consider it to have that quality.
認為…有（重要性、價值、意義等）

attach yourself to: If you attach yourself to a person or group, you join him, her, or it, usually for a limited period of time.
（通常在有限的時間內）與…在一起；成為…的成員；參加

attach\u00e9 case: a rectangular case with hard sides, used especially for carrying business documents

attend to: to help someone or deal with something

attention deficit hyperactivity disorder: a condition in which someone, especially a child, is often in a state of activity or excitement and unable to direct their attention towards what they are doing
（尤指兒童的）注意力缺乏，過度活躍症，過動症

attention span: the length of time that someone can keep their thoughts and interest fixed on something
集中力時間（指將心思和興趣集中於某一事物的時間長度）

attorney general: the top legal officer in some countries, whose job is to provide legal advice to the government and to represent the government
（某些國家的）檢察總長，首席檢察官；司法部長

atypical lipoma: a soft mass of fat cells that grows under the skin and is found in the fat cell tissues on the back of the neck, shoulders, and back

au fait: to be familiar with or know about something

au gratin: cooked with a covering of cheese or breadcrumbs mixed with butter
帶脆皮的（外皮由起司或麵包碎加奶油製成）

au pair: a foreign person, usually a young woman, who lives with a family in order to learn their language and who takes care of the children or cleans the house in return for meals, a room, and a small payment
互惠生，換工（在國外為學習外語住在當地人家裡，以照顧孩子或做家務換取食宿和小額報酬，通常是年輕女性）

auction house: a company whose business is selling things at auction

auction of promises: an occasion when people bid (= offer money and compete against other people) for something that someone has offered to do, for example cook a meal, wash a car, etc. It is usually done in order to get money for a charity.

auditory brainstem implant: an electronic device that is put into the brain of a deaf person during an operation so they can hear some sounds

auditory nerve: a nerve in the ear that carries electrical signals from the inner ear to the brain
聽覺神經（將內耳中的電訊號傳遞到大腦的神經）

augmented reality: images produced by a computer and used together with a view of the real world

Auld Lang Syne: a traditional Scottish song with words by the poet Robert Burns, often sung at New Year to say goodbye to the old year and welcome the new year. Auld lang syne means "the old days" in Scots.
《友誼萬歲》（又譯《友誼地久天長》，蘇格蘭民間歌曲，羅伯特·彭斯作詞，通常在歲末辭舊迎新時唱起。Auld lang syne在蘇格蘭語中意為「過去的時光」）

Aussie Rules: 澳式足球，澳式橄欖球（同 Australian Rules）

Australian English: the English language as it is spoken and written in Australia

Australian Rules: a sport played in Australia between two teams of 18 players. The players can run with the ball, which is oval, and can kick or hit it.
澳式足球，澳式橄欖球（澳大利亞的一種體育運動，比賽的兩支隊伍每隊上場18人，球呈橄欖型，可以帶球奔跑、腳踢或手擊。）

autoimmune disease: a disease in which a person's immune system wrongly attacks its own healthy tissues

autoimmune liver disease: a disease in which someone's immune system attacks their liver, making it swollen and painful and perhaps causing the person to develop hepatitis

autoimmune pancreatitis: a condition in which someone's pancreas becomes swollen and painful, making them lose weight and develop jaundice (= a disease in which the skin turns yellow)

automatic pilot: （飛機等的）自動駕駛儀（同 autopilot）

automatic transmission: a system that allows a vehicle to change gear without being controlled by the driver
（車輛的）自動變速器，自動排檔

autonomic nervous system: the part of the nervous system that controls automatic processes such as breathing, digestion, and the beating of the heart

autosomal dominant polycystic kidney dis: a genetic disease that makes cysts (= small growths filled with liquid) develop on the kidneys, sometimes causing the kidneys to stop working. It mainly affects adults
自體顯性遺傳多囊性腎病

autosomal recessive polycystic kidney di: a rare physical problem present from birth that makes the kidneys become larger and develop cysts (= small growths filled with liquid), leading to very serious kidney disease. It mainly affects children.
自體隱性遺傳多囊性腎病

autumn years: Someone's autumn years are the later years of their life, especially after they have stopped working.

auxiliary nurse: someone whose job is to help nurses to take care of people

average out: to calculate the average of a set of numbers or amounts

average out at: to have a particular number or amount as the average
算出的平均值是，平均為

aversion therapy: a method of treating habits or types of behaviour that are not wanted or not acceptable, by causing the patient to connect them with bad feelings
厭惡療法（引起患者對自己的有害習慣或行為的厭惡，以達到戒除目的）

avian flu: an illness that kills birds and can sometimes pass from birds to people
禽流感（可造成禽類死亡，也可傳染給人類）

aw shucks: used to show that you feel embarrassed or shy

awake brain surgery: surgery on the brain performed when the patient is awake and able to respond to commands so that the function of the brain and nerves can be tested during the operation

awaken in: If a wish, interest, or emotion awakens or is awakened in you, you notice it for the first time.
喚起（或激起）某人的（慾望、興趣、情緒等）

Axis Powers: Germany, Italy, and Japan during World War II
（第二次世界大戰中的）軸心國

Ayurvedic medicine: a traditional system of medicine from India in which illnesses are treated with a combination of certain foods, herbs, massage, and special physical exercise

B and B: （私人住宅或小旅館提供的）住宿和早餐，民宿（bed and breakfast的縮寫）

B variant GM2 gangliosidosis: a genetic disease in which the body is unable to get rid of a fatty substance called ganglioside so that it builds up in the brain. This causes the nerves to stop working properly and eventually leads to death, usually before the age of three
GM2神經節苷脂症變異型B，GM2神經節苷脂貯積病變異型B

LETTER: the second letter of the English alphabet
（英文字母表的第二個字母）
MARK: a mark in an exam or for a piece of work that shows that your work is good but not excellent
（學業成績、工作表現）良好，乙等成績

baby blues: a feeling of sadness that some women experience after they have given birth to a baby
部分女性在分娩後經歷的一種憂鬱情緒；產後憂鬱症

baby boom: a large increase in the number of babies born among a particular group of people during a particular time

baby carriage: a vehicle for moving a baby around that consists of a small bed supported by a frame on four wheels

baby fat: fat that a child sometimes has that disappears as the child grows older
兒童時期的肥胖（長大後即消失）

baby milk: a type of milk that can be given to babies instead of milk from their mother

baby step: an act that makes a very small amount of progress towards achieving something

baby talk: the words that a very young child uses, or the words used by adults when they talk to babies
兒語；（成人對嬰兒用的）模仿兒語

baby tooth: one of the teeth of young children and some other young mammals that fall out and are replaced by permanent teeth

bachelor party: a party for a man who is going to get married, to which only his male friends are invited
（婚禮前夕為新郎舉行，只有男性朋友參加的）告別單身派對

bachelor's degree: a first degree at college or university

bachelorette party: a party for a woman who is going to get married, to which only her female friends are invited
（婚禮前夕為新娘舉行，只有女性朋友參加的）告別單身派對

back alley: a narrow passage behind or between buildings, especially in the older and poorer areas of a town or city
陋巷（建築物後或之間的狹窄通道，尤指市鎮相對破舊、貧窮地區的）

back and forth: moving first in one direction and then in the opposite one

back away: to move backwards away from something or someone, usually because you are frightened
to show that you do not support a plan or idea any longer and do not want to be involved with it

back copy: a newspaper or magazine of an earlier date than the one now on sale

back door: a door at the back or side of a building, or at the back of a vehicle
used to refer to an indirect way of achieving something, especially so that people do not know about it and so cannot object to it
（比喻意義的）後門，不正當的秘密途徑

back down: to admit that you were wrong or that you have been defeated

back east: to or in the east of the US
往美國東部；在美國東部

back four: on a football team, the two centre halfs and the two fullbacks, who together form the defence
（足球的）四衛式（通常由兩名後衛和兩名中衛組成的戰術陣形）

back in the day: used for talking about a time in the past, usually when you are remembering nice things about that time
曾幾何時（尤用於追憶美好往事時）

back off: to stop being involved in a situation, usually in order to allow other people to deal with it themselves
放棄；放手；停止（指手畫腳）
to move backwards away from someone, usually because you are frightened

back office: the part of a business company that is concerned with running the company and that does not deal directly with customers or the public

back onto: If a building backs onto something, its back faces that thing.

back out: to decide not to do something that you had said you would do

back pages: UK the back part of a newspaper, which usually has news relating to sport
報紙的最後幾頁（一般是體育新聞）

back pass: an intentional pass backwards to the goalkeeper
（足球比賽中故意傳給守門員的）回傳球

back road: a small road that does not have much traffic on it

back saw: a small tool with a sharp, thin blade and a strong metal back

SEAT BEHIND DRIVER: the seat behind the front seat of a car

back story: the things that have happened to someone before you first see or read about that person in a film or story

back the wrong horse: to make the wrong decision and support a person or action that is later unsuccessful
下錯了賭注；看錯人；作了錯誤的決策

back to square one: If you are back to square one, you have to start working on a plan from the beginning because your previous attempt failed completely.

back up: to make an extra copy of computer information

back-alley abortion: 非法秘密墮胎（同 backstreet abortion）

backed up: If traffic is backed up, the vehicles have to wait in a long line because there are too many of them.

background radiation: radiation found naturally on earth that comes from some soil, rocks, etc., and from outer space
背景輻射（可在地球檢測到自然存在的輻射，來自外太空以及土壤和岩石等物質）

backroom boys: people in an organization whose work is not seen by or is kept secret from the public

backseat driver: a passenger in a car who keeps giving the driver advice that he or she has not asked for
胡亂指點司機的乘客；多管閒事的人

backstreet abortion: an illegal and usually dangerous operation to end a pregnancy done by someone who is not medically trained

backup software: computer programs that automatically create copies of the information on a computer system so that it can be stored separately and used to replace the original information if it is damaged or lost

bad blood: feelings of hate between people because of arguments in the past

bad debt: a debt, or debt, that is not likely to be paid

bad faith: done in a dishonest way with the intention of tricking someone

bad feeling: 感情不和；嫌隙，仇恨（同 bad blood）
a situation in which people are upset or angry with each other

bad hair day: a day when you feel that you do not look attractive, especially because of your hair, and everything seems to go wrong
不如意的一天，倒楣的日子

bad language: words that are considered offensive by most people

bad luck!: said to express sympathy with someone when something bad has happened to them
太倒楣了！真不走運！太不湊巧！

tough luck!: said to express sympathy with someone when something bad has happened to them
太倒楣了！真不走運！太不湊巧！

badly off: having little money and few of the things you need to live

bag for life: a strong plastic shopping bag that you buy cheaply from a supermarket and use many times, usually one that the supermarket replaces when it is broken and then recycles
（超級市場裡購買的）可回收塑膠購物袋，環保袋

bag lady: a woman who has no home and carries everything that she owns around with her in bags
無家可歸的女人；帶著行李露宿街頭的女人

baggage allowance: the weight or number of cases and bags that you are allowed to take onto an aircraft without paying extra

baggage car: a railway carriage in which large bags are transported

baggage handler: a person who takes passengers' bags and cases and puts them onto or removes them from an aircraft

baggage room: a place at a station, airport, etc. where you can leave your bags for a short time until you need them

used when you claim the right to have something or do something

Bahasa Malaysia: the official language of Malaysia, which is a form of the Malay language

bail out: to remove water from the bottom of a boat

baked Alaska: a dish consisting of a cake base with ice cream on top covered with meringue (= a mixture made of sugar and the white part of eggs) that is cooked for a very short time at a high temperature
火焰霜淇淋（美國的一種霜淇淋，底部為蛋糕，上面蓋有糖和蛋白混合製成的酥皮，在高溫下以極短時間烘焙而成）

baked beans: beans that have been cooked in tomato sauce, sugar, and spices. In the UK, these are usually sold in tins
茄汁焗豆（通常製成罐頭）

baked goods: food products that have been baked in an oven, for example cakes, biscuits, and bread

baked potato: a potato baked whole with its skin

baking powder: a mixture of powders used to make cakes rise and become light when they are baked

baking sheet: a flat metal dish used to cook things in an oven

baking soda: a white powder used to make foods rise when they are baked

baking tray: a sheet of metal with low sides, used for baking food

balance out: to be equal in amount or value, or to make things equal in amount or value

balance up: to be equal in amount or value, or to make things equal in amount or value

balance of payments: the difference between the money that a country receives from exports and the money that it spends on imports

balance of power: a position in which both or all of the groups or people involved, usually in a political situation, have equal power

balance sheet: a statement that shows the value of a company's assets (= things of positive value) and its debts

balanced diet: a combination of the correct types and amounts of food

balanced equation: a chemical equation that has an equal amount of each element on the left and right sides
平衡的化學方程式（方程式左右兩邊每種元素的數量相等）

balancing act: a situation in which a person tries to give care and attention to two or more activities at the same time

bald eagle: a large North American eagle with a white head, used as a symbol of the US

bald patch: an area of a person's head that has no hair

Balint's syndrome: a condition that makes someone unable to see anything in the outer areas of the visual field (= the area that can be seen without moving the head)

ball bearing: a small metal ball or several of these arranged in a ring to make particular parts of a machine move more easily

ball boy: a boy/girl who picks up balls during a tennis or football game and gives them back to the players
（網球比賽中負責撿球的）球童

ball girl: a boy/girl who picks up balls during a tennis or football game and gives them back to the players
（網球比賽中負責撿球的）球童

ball game: any game that is played with a ball

ball-and-socket joint: a joint (= a place where two bones are connected) consisting of a round end and a hollow socket that fit together and move easily

ballet shoe: a type of soft, flat shoe worn by ballet dancers

ballistic missile: a missile (= flying weapon) that has power in order to direct it on its flight, but that continues and falls towards its target without power

ballot box: a box into which people put their voting slips when voting
used to refer to elections or other occasions when people officially vote

ballot rigging: the practice of using illegal methods to obtain a particular result in an election

ballpoint pen: a pen with a small metal ball at the end that puts ink on the paper

ballroom dancing: a type of dancing where two people use special steps and movements to do dances such as the waltz or tango together
交際舞，交誼舞（如華爾滋或探戈）

balls up: to spoil something by making a mistake or doing something stupid

balsa wood: very light wood that is soft and easily cut, sometimes used in making models of aircraft, etc.

balsamic vinegar: a type of sweet, dark Italian vinegar made from grapes in a traditional way

banana republic: a small country, especially in South and Central America, that is poor, corrupt, and badly ruled
香蕉共和國（尤指貧窮且政府統治無道的中南美洲小國）

banana skin: a sudden unexpected situation that makes a person appear silly or causes them difficulty
使人出醜（或引起麻煩）的突發事件

banana split: a sweet dish made of a banana cut in half with ice cream and cream on top
香蕉新地（霜淇淋）；香蕉船霜淇淋

band together: to join together as a group in order to be able to do something better

band-aid solution: a temporary solution that does not deal with the cause of a problem

bang goes: said when you have just lost the opportunity to do something

bang on: to talk about something for a long time, especially in a way that is boring to other people
喋喋不休，說個沒完沒了

bang up: to lock someone up, especially in prison

bang the drum: to speak enthusiastically about a belief or idea in order to persuade other people to support it too

beat the drum: to speak enthusiastically about a belief or idea in order to persuade other people to support it too

bank account: an arrangement with a bank in which the customer puts in and removes money and the bank keeps a record of it

bank balance: the amount of money in a bank account

bank card: a plastic card given to you by your bank, that you can use to pay for things or to take money out of your account

bank charges: amounts of money paid by a customer for a bank's services

bank holiday: an official holiday when banks and most businesses are closed for a day
銀行公休日（銀行和大多數公司均不營業）

bank manager: the person in charge of a local bank

bank on: to expect something or depend on something happening

bank rate: the rate of interest set by a central bank in a country that is the lowest rate at which it lends money to other banks. This rate affects the interest rates that are then charged to customers by the banks.
（中央銀行規定的）銀行貼現率；銀行利率；（尤指）最低貸率
the amount of interest that a bank charges when it lends money

bank statement: a record of the money put into and removed from a bank account

banker's order: （客戶向銀行下達的）定期付款，按期付款委託書（同 standing order）

banner advertisement: an advertisement that appears across the top of a page on the internet or in a newspaper
（網際網路或報紙上的）橫幅廣告，廣告條

banner headline: a large title of a story in a newspaper that stretches across the top of the front page

banoffee pie: a sweet dish made from bananas, cream, and toffee on pastry
香蕉太妃派（一款甜點，用油酥糕配以香蕉、奶油和太妃糖製成）

bar chart: a mathematical picture in which different amounts are represented by thin vertical or horizontal rectangles that have the same width but different heights or lengths

bar code: a small rectangular pattern of thick and thin black lines printed on a product, or on its container, so that the details of the product can be read by and recorded on a computer system

bar line: a vertical line that divides one bar from another in a written piece of music

bar mitzvah: a Jewish ceremony held to celebrate a boy reaching the age of 13, in which he is given the religious responsibilities and duties of an adult man
受戒禮（為年滿13歲的猶太男孩舉行的成人儀式）

bar stool: a tall seat with no support for the back or arms, for sitting on while drinking or eating at a bar

barbecue sauce: a spicy sauce that is used to flavour food cooked on a barbecue

barbed wire: a type of strong wire with sharp points on it, used to prevent people or animals from entering or leaving a place, especially a field

barber's pole: a pole with red and white stripes that traditionally is put on the front of a barbershop
（位於理髮店外作為招牌的紅白條）旋轉標誌彩柱

bare infinitive: in grammar, the infinitive form of a verb without the word "to"
不帶 to 的動詞不定式

bare your heart: to tell someone your secret thoughts and feelings

bare your soul: to tell someone your secret thoughts and feelings

barf bag: a waterproof paper bag provided for each passenger on an aircraft in case they need to vomit

bargain basement: an underground room in a shop where things are sold at reduced prices

bargain bin: a container in a shop, with things in it that you can buy at a reduced price
商店中用於裝打折商品的容器

bargain for: to expect or be prepared for something

bargain on: to expect or be prepared for something

bargaining chip: something that someone else wants that you are willing to lose in order to reach an agreement

bargaining power: the ability of a person or group to get what they want
討價還價的能力；談判的能力

barge in: to walk into a room quickly, without being invited

bariatric surgery: an operation that makes the stomach smaller so that less food can be eaten and digested
減肥手術（縮小胃容量以減少食量）

barium meal: a chemical, barium sulphate, that is swallowed by a person just before an X-ray is taken of their stomach and bowels, so that these organs can be seen clearly

barium sulphate: a chemical used in industry and medicine

barley sugar: a hard sweet made from boiled sugar

barley water: UK a drink made from barley and fruit juice
US old-fashioned a drink made from barley and water boiled together and given to someone who is sick to make them feel better

barn dance: an informal dance in which people do traditional dancing in rows and circles, changing partners regularly

barometric pressure: the amount of force at any point on the earth's surface caused by the weight of the air

barrack for: to shout encouragement to the players in a team

barrage balloon: a large balloon, especially one of a group that is tied to the ground with metal ropes in order to stop enemy aircraft that are flying low

barrel organ: a large musical instrument that plays music when you turn a handle on the side. In the past, barrel organs were played outside to entertain people.

barrel roll: a movement of an aircraft in which it turns over and then back up again

Barrett's oesophagus: a condition in which the cells of the oesophagus change in a way that is not normal, often as a result of acid reflux (= a condition where stomach acid comes back up into the oesophagus)
巴瑞特食道症，巴氏食道症

barrier cream: a cream that stops dirt or chemicals from getting through to the skin

barrow boy: in the past, a man or boy who sold fruit and vegetables, etc. from a barrow

basal cell carcinoma: a type of skin cancer that grows slowly and often affects parts of the body that have had a lot of exposure to the sun
基底細胞癌，皮膚基底細胞癌

base camp: a place where food and general supplies are kept, especially for people climbing a mountain

base form: in grammar, the simplest form of a verb, without a special ending

base hit: (in baseball) a play in which a player hits the ball and successfully reaches first base

base jumping: the sport of jumping from a high building, bridge, etc. with a parachute
定點跳傘運動（從如高建築物或橋等高處跳下，借助降落傘著地的運動）

base metal: a common metal, such as lead, tin, or copper, that reacts easily with other chemicals and is not a precious metal

base pay: the basic amount of money that someone is paid for doing a job, not including any extra amounts such as overtime payments or bonuses

base rate: a rate (= level of interest) decided by the Bank of England that banks use when deciding how much to charge for lending money

baseball cap: a tightly fitting hat, originally worn by baseball players, with a long flat piece at the front to protect the eyes from the sun

baseball jacket: a jacket, often with sleeves that are a different colour to the rest of the jacket, that fits tightly round the waist and fastens with a zip

bash on: to continue doing something that is difficult, boring, or takes a long time

bask in: to take pleasure from something that makes you feel good

bask in reflected glory: to feel successful and admired for something, despite the fact that you did not achieve it yourself but were only connected to it in some way
因為別人的成就而沾光；分享別人的榮譽

bathe in reflected glory: to feel successful and admired for something, despite the fact that you did not achieve it yourself but were only connected to it in some way
因為別人的成就而沾光；分享別人的榮譽

PERSON: informal someone who is extremely nervous or anxious and is therefore unable to organize their life
極度緊張（或焦慮）的人；精神瀕於崩潰的人
COUNTRY/COMPANY: a country or company that is very unsuccessful financially
財政拮据的國家（或公司）

bass clef: a sign on a stave (= the five lines on which music is written) that shows that the notes are below middle C (= the C near the middle of a piano keyboard)

bass drum: a large drum that produces a low sound

basset hound: a type of dog with smooth hair, a long body, short legs, and long ears
巴色特獵犬，短腿長耳獵犬

bat mitzvah: a Jewish ceremony held to celebrate a girl reaching the age of twelve, in which she is given the religious responsibilities and duties of an adult woman
女受戒禮（為年滿13歲的猶太女孩舉行的成人儀式）

bath cubes: small, hard objects with six equal square sides that you dissolve in bath water to make it smell pleasant or to make your skin soft

bath mat: a piece of material that you stand on after getting out of a bath or shower to stop the floor from getting wet, or a piece of rubber that is put inside the bath or shower to prevent you sliding and falling

bath rack: a set of metal bars or an open plastic container that is put across a bath and used to hold soap, etc.

bath salts: grains of a substance that you dissolve in bath water to make it smell pleasant or to make your skin soft

bath towel: a large towel with which you dry yourself after a bath or shower

bathing costume: a piece of clothing that you wear for swimming

bathing suit: a piece of clothing that you wear for swimming

bathroom fittings: the pieces of furniture that are in a bathroom, such as a toilet, bath, etc.

be in good shape: to be prepared and ready to do something

be in good, the best possible, etc. tast: to be acceptable in a way that will not upset or anger people

be in hot water: to be in or get into a difficult situation in which you are in danger of being criticized or punished

be in league with: to be secretly working or planning something with someone, usually to do something bad

be in no mood for sth/to do: to not want to do something, often because you are angry

be in one of your moods: If a person is in one of their moods, they are being unfriendly and angry in a way that is typical of them.

be in over your head: to be involved in a difficult situation that you cannot get out of

be in sb's face: If someone is in your face, they criticize you all the time.

be in sb's good/bad books: If you are in someone's good/bad books, they are pleased/not pleased with you.

be in sb's shoes: to be in the situation, usually a bad or difficult situation, that another person is in

be in the right ballpark: to be close to the right amount

be in the ballpark: to be close to the right amount

be in the bag: If something is in the bag, you are certain to get it or to achieve it.

be in the black: If a bank account is in the black, it contains some money, and if a person or business is in the black, they have money in the bank and are not in debt.

be in the clear: to not be guilty of a crime
to have no problems after being in a difficult situation

be in the dark: to not know about something that other people know about

be in the driving seat: to be in charge or in control of a situation

be in the first flush of: to be at the start of something

be in the land of the living: to be awake or to be alive

be in the loop/be out of the loop: to have or not have the special knowledge or power that belongs to a particular group of people

be in the middle of: to be busy with an activity

be in the money: to suddenly have a lot of money

be in the mood: to feel like doing or having something

be in the public eye: to be famous and written about in newspapers and magazines and seen on television

be in the red: If you or your bank account are in the red, you owe money to the bank.

be in the same ballpark: to be of a similar amount or cost

be in the same boat: to be in the same unpleasant situation as other people
在同一艘船上； 處境相同，面臨同樣的困境；

be in the soup: to be in an unpleasant or difficult situation

be in the wars: to have injuries to many different parts of the body

be in the/sb's blood: If an ability or skill is in someone's blood, they have it naturally, usually because it already exists in their family.

be in two minds: to be unable to decide about something

be in your element: to be happy because you are doing what you like or can do best

be in/get into a lather: to be or become very worried or nervous about something

be in/go into high gear: informal to be or become very active, exciting, or productive
變得非常活躍（或興奮、高效）

be in/out of luck: to be able/unable to have or do what you want
能夠／未能如願，運氣好／差

be in/under sb's shadow: to always receive less attention than someone else

be joined in marriage: to become a married couple in an official ceremony

be joined in matrimony: to become a married couple in an official ceremony

be just as well: to be a good thing to do, or to be a lucky thing to happen or be done

be just the job: to be exactly what you want or need

be kind, generous, etc. to a fault: to be extremely kind, generous, etc.

be knee-high to a grasshopper: to be very small or young

to have almost reached a particular, usually old, age

to have almost reached a particular, usually old, age

be known to be: If something or someone is known to be or do something, people know that it is true or happens, or that someone is or does something.

be known to do: If something or someone is known to be or do something, people know that it is true or happens, or that someone is or does something.

be laid up: to be forced to stay in bed because of an illness or accident

be laughed out of court: to be considered as too silly or impossible to take seriously, especially in a law court

be laughing all the way to the bank: to be earning a lot of money easily
輕易發大財，輕鬆賺大錢

be laughing: used to tell someone that they should not be worried by a particular situation, because they will get an advantage from it

be laughing on the other side of your fa: used to tell someone that, despite being pleased now, they will not be pleased later when things do not happen as expected or planned

be left holding the baby: to suddenly have to deal with a difficult situation because others have decided that they do not want the responsibility

be like a deer/rabbit caught in the head: to be so frightened or surprised that you cannot move or think

be like a fish out of water: to feel awkward because you are in a situation that you have not experienced before or because you are very different from the people around you

be like a red rag to a bull: to be certain to produce an angry or violent reaction

be like chalk and cheese: If two people are like chalk and cheese, they are completely different from each other.

be like feeding time at the zoo: to be very noisy and untidy and have no order

be like talking to a brick wall: If talking to someone is like talking to a brick wall, the person you are speaking to does not listen.

be locked in: to be prevented from moving by something
If you are locked in a situation or process, it is impossible for you to escape or make progress from it.

be locked together: If people or animals are locked together, they are holding each other tightly so that neither one can move.

be long in the tooth: to be old, often too old to do something
年老；（常指）年紀太大（而無法做某事）

be looking for trouble: to be acting in a way that will certainly cause problems for you

be lost for words: to be so shocked, surprised, full of admiration, etc. that you cannot speak

be made for: to be exactly suitable for someone or something

be marked out as: to be shown to be different because of a certain characteristic

be meant for each other: If you say two people are meant for each other, you think they suit each other as romantic partners.

be meat and drink to: If a difficult or unpleasant activity is meat and drink to someone, they enjoy doing it very much and find it easy.

be miles away: to not be conscious of what is happening around you because you are thinking about something else

be mixed up with: to be connected with a bad or unpleasant person or thing

be mixed up in: to be connected with a bad or unpleasant person or thing

be more to this than meets the eye: If there is more to something than meets the eye, it is more difficult to understand or involves more things than you thought at the beginning.

be murder: to be very difficult to do

be murder on: informal to be painful or harmful for something

be music to sb's ears: to be something that you are very pleased to hear

be my guest!: something you say when you give someone permission to do or use something

be neither fish nor fowl: like one thing in some ways and like another thing in other ways

be neither one thing nor the other: to be a mixture of two different things, often things that do not combine well

be new to this game: to be involved in an activity or situation that you have not experienced before

be news to: to be information that someone did not know before

be no hard and fast rules: If there are no hard and fast rules, there are no clear rules for you to follow.

be no skin off sb's nose: used when you want to say that it makes no difference to you what someone else does or thinks

be no slouch: If you say that someone is no slouch at a particular activity, you mean that they work hard at it and produce good results.

be no stranger to: to be familiar with a particular experience or activity

be no/little love lost between: If there is no/little love lost between two people, they do not like each other.

be none of sb's business: If something is none of someone's business, they do not need to know about it.

be none the wiser: to still be confused about something even after it has been explained to you

be none the worse: to not be harmed or damaged by something

be not quite right in the head: to not have one or more of the mental abilities that most people have

be not right in the head: to not have one or more of the mental abilities that most people have

be not all there: to be slightly stupid or strange

be not on: Something that is not on is unacceptable and should not happen.

used to emphasize a situation, quality, or type of behaviour

並不優秀（或漂亮）；毫無特別之處

be nothing to get excited about: 不是特別好的；並非特別出眾的

be nothing to it: used to say something is very easy

be of/have no fixed abode: to not have a permanent home

be off your chump: to be extremely silly or stupid

be on guard: to be careful to avoid being tricked or getting into a dangerous situation

US to be officially recorded, especially as a law

be put upon: to be treated badly by someone who takes advantage of your wish to be helpful

be quick/slow on the uptake: If someone is quick/slow on the uptake, they understand things easily/with difficulty.

be ready to do: informal to be going to do something immediately
to be willing to do something

to be going to leave soon

be resigned to: If you are resigned to something unpleasant, you calmly accept that it will happen.

be riding for a fall: to be behaving in a way that is likely to lead you into trouble

be rolling in it: 非常富有，財源滾滾，腰纏萬貫

be rolling in the aisles: to laugh without being able stop

be rotten to the core: If a person or organization is rotten to the core, they behave in a way that is not honest or moral.

mainly US and Australian English If a person or an organization is running on empty, they have no new ideas or are not as effective as they were before.

be sb's bag: If something is your bag, you are interested in it and do it for pleasure.

be set fair: (of the weather) to be clear and dry and not changing or expected to change

be set on: to be determined to do something

be set upon: to be determined to do something

be sitting pretty: to be in a good situation, usually because you have a lot of money

（比另一物或人）好得多，明顯領先

be the image of: to look very similar to someone

（尤指為了開始與某人建立戀愛關係）請…外出（或吃飯、看電影等）

assign to: to choose someone to do a particular job

attribute to: to say or think that something is the result or work of something or someone else
把…歸因於…；認為…由…產生；認為…是…所為

attribute to sb: to say or think that something is the result or work of something or someone else
把…歸因於…；認為…由…產生；認為…是…所為

avoid like the plague: to be determined to avoid something completely
像避瘟疫一樣躲避，堅決避開

awaken to: If you awaken someone to something, you make them notice it or make them remember it.
使（某人）意識到；使（某人）認識到

balance against: to compare the advantages and disadvantages of something

bandy around: to mention something often, without considering it carefully

bargain away: to exchange something good for something of less value
以高價值物品交換低價值物品

base on: If you base something on facts or ideas, you use those facts or ideas to develop it.

bawl out: to tell someone angrily that something they have done is wrong

be more to than meets the eye: If there is more to something than meets the eye, it is more difficult to understand or involves more things than you thought at the beginning.
比開始認為的還要難應付；比當初看上去的更複雜

be plenty more where came from: to be a lot more things or people of the same type available

bear out: to support the truth of something

beat at their own game: to use to your own advantage the methods by which someone else has tried to defeat you
以其人之道還治其人之身

beat hollow: to defeat someone easily and by a large amount
輕而易舉擊敗，取得壓倒性勝利

beat out: to make sounds that have a particular rhythm by hitting something such as a drum
打拍子；用鼓拍打出節拍；敲打伴奏
to make a fire go out by hitting it repeatedly with an object, such as a large piece of cloth

beat to a jelly: to hit someone repeatedly and forcefully

beat to a pulp: to hit someone repeatedly until they are badly injured

beat back: to use force to move someone or something away from you

beat out of: to make someone say things they do not want to by hitting them

bed out: to move young or delicate plants from inside and plant them outside

beef up: to make something stronger or more important

believe when you see it: If you say you will believe something when you see it, you mean you think it will not happen.

belt out: to sing or play a musical instrument very loudly

big up: to talk a lot about how excellent someone or something is, sometimes praising him, her, or it more than is deserved

bind to: to force someone to keep a promise

blank out: to intentionally cover over something that is written so that it cannot be read
to stop yourself thinking about a memory because it is unpleasant and you would prefer not to remember it
刻意忘記，抹去對…的記憶

blast to kingdom come: to destroy someone or something completely using a gun or bomb
徹底炸毀；（用炮彈）送…上西天

blow to kingdom come: to destroy someone or something completely using a gun or bomb
徹底炸毀；（用炮彈）送…上西天

bleed dry: to take a lot of money from someone over a period of time

blind with science: to confuse someone by using difficult or technical words to describe something

block off: to close a road, path, or entrance so that people cannot use it

block out: to stop light or noise from passing through something
to stop yourself from thinking about an unpleasant memory because it upsets you

block up: to fill a narrow space with something so that nothing can pass through

block in: to put a vehicle so close to another vehicle that it cannot drive away

blot out: to hide or block the light from something, especially the sun
to stop yourself thinking about something unpleasant

blow away: to defeat someone or something completely, especially in a sports competition
（尤指在體育比賽中）徹底戰勝…

blow out of proportion: to treat a particular event or problem far too seriously
對（事情或問題）小題大做

blow off: to treat something or someone as if that thing or person were not important

blow out of the water: to destroy or defeat something or someone completely
（以壓倒性姿態）戰勝…；徹底擊垮…

blow, bomb, wipe, etc. off the map: to destroy a place or thing completely, especially with bombs
（尤指用炸彈）徹底毀掉，完全摧毀

blurt out: to say something suddenly and without thinking, usually because you are excited or nervous
脫口説出，不假思索地説

board up: to cover a door or window with wooden boards

bollocks up: to spoil something by making mistakes

bolt on: to add an extra part or feature

bombard with: to direct so many things at someone, especially to ask them so many questions, that they find it difficult to deal with them
拿…圍攻…；（尤指）向…大量提問

book in/book into: to arrange for someone to stay at a hotel

boot off: informal to force someone to stop taking part in an activity

boot out: informal to force someone to leave a job or not allow them to continue with an activity

bottle up: When a person bottles things up, they refuse to talk about things that make them angry or worried.

bounce into: to force someone to do something that they do not want to do, usually relating to politics
（通常指在政治上）迫使…做（不願做的事）

bounce off: If you bounce something off someone, you tell someone about an idea or plan in order to find out what they think of it.

bowl out: in the game of cricket, to make someone have to leave the cricket field by hitting the wicket (= three vertical sticks) behind them with the ball
（板球運動中）撃中三柱門把（打撃手）殺出局

bowl over: to knock someone to the ground by running into them
to surprise and please someone a lot

box in: to move so close to someone or something that the person or thing cannot move away

brazen out: to act confidently and not admit that a problem exists

bring around: to make someone become conscious again after being unconscious
to persuade someone to have the same opinion as you have

bring down: to reduce the level of something

bring in: to introduce something new such as a product or a law
引進（新産品等）；制定，提出（新法律）

bring on: to make something happen, usually something bad
said to show that you are prepared and willing to compete in a competition or to do something difficult
（表示作好準備迎接挑戰）來吧！

bring out: to produce something to sell to the public
to make a particular quality or detail noticeable

bring out in: If something brings you out in spots, a rash, etc., it causes spots to appear on your skin.

bring to: UK to make someone become conscious again after being unconscious

bring to book: to punish someone and make that person explain their behaviour
懲罸（某人）並要求其作出解釋

bring up: to start to talk about a particular subject

bring up short: to make someone suddenly stop doing something or talking, usually because they are surprised

bring along: to take someone or something with you

bring to their knees: to destroy or defeat someone or something

bring together: to cause people to be friendly with each other

bring back: to return from somewhere with something
to make someone think about something from the past
to start to do or use something that was done or used in the past

bring forward: to introduce something so that it can be seen or discussed
mainly UK to change the date or time of an event so that it happens earlier than planned

bring home: to make someone understand something much more clearly than they did before, especially something unpleasant
（讓某人）更清楚地理解（尤指不愉快的事）

bring off: to succeed in doing something difficult

bring to light: If someone brings something to light, they discover it or make it known publicly.

bring to the party: to have something such as a good quality to offer in a situation
擁有在某特定情況下的優秀特質

bring to heel: to order a dog to come close to you
to force someone to obey you

call to heel: to order a dog to come close to you
to force someone to obey you

bring down a peg: to show someone that they are not as important as they thought
煞（某人的）威風，挫（某人的）傲氣

take down a peg: to show someone that they are not as important as they thought
煞（某人的）威風，挫（某人的）傲氣

brush aside: to refuse to consider something seriously because you feel that it is not important

brush off: to refuse to listen to what someone says, or to refuse to think about something seriously

bugger up: to damage something or cause problems by doing something stupid

build in: to include something as part of a plan, system, or agreement
（使）包括；使成為（計劃、系統或協議的）組成部分

build into: to include something as part of a plan, system, or agreement
（使）包括；使成為（計劃、系統或協議的）組成部分

bulk out: to make something bigger or thicker by adding something

bum out: US informal to make someone feel sad or disappointed

bump up: to increase the amount or size of something

bung up: to cause something to be blocked so that it does not work in the way it should

burn off: to use or get rid of energy or fat by doing a lot of physical exercise
（透過大量體育鍛煉）消耗（能量或脂肪）

butter up: to be very kind or friendly to someone or try to please someone, so that that person will do what you want them to do

buy off: to pay someone so that they do not cause you any trouble

buy out: to buy a part of a company or building from someone else so that you own all of it

buy in: to buy something for future use and not because you need it now

buy up: To buy something up is to buy large amounts of it, or all that is available.

call in: If a bank calls in money, it demands that you pay back the money it has lent to you.

call up: to find and show information on a computer screen
（在電腦螢幕上）顯示，調出（資訊）

call off: to decide that a planned event, especially a sports event, will not happen, or to end an activity because it is no longer useful or possible
取消，停止，中止（尤指體育賽事）

cancel out: to remove the effect of one thing by doing another thing that has the opposite effect
